_prev_prog_2.FR_OtherType: Applicable building, electrical and plumbing codes. This facility complies with the Iowa fertilizer Law.
_prev_prog_2.FR_Comments: We utilize those portions of these codes which are deemed applicable by the jurisdictional authority
_prev_prog_2.MH_OtherType: Train derailment and vandalism/theft; vehicular protection; potential leaking from underground piping
_prev_prog_2.PC_OtherType: Remote shutoff, automatic by-pass, pull away protection
_prev_prog_2.MS_OtherType: Regular plant inspections / Toutine preventive maintenance & repair
_prev_prog_2.CH_OtherChanges: Recommendations, if any have been made, have been or arrangements have been made to have them completed on or before June 30, 2008
_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: Pumps, pump seals, pipes and plumbing, valves, electrical and safety equipment. The breakaway couplers, pressure relief valves and hoses are also inspected and replaced as necessary
_prev_prog_2.Description: The plan is to minimize those hazards to human health and to the environment that are associated with accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia. Employees working at the bulk storage plant make routine observations prior to and during transfer operations of the anhydrous ammonia from the storage vessel(s) to nurse tanks. In so doing, they are able to detect problems before they arise. This routine inspection identifies any external portion of the system which may be under stress or about to fail. Repairs can be made before they become problematic. Employees are annually trained to recognize hazards associated with storage and handling of anhydrous ammonia. In addition to annual training for employees who have been on the job for a number of years, the company conducts training for new hires. This training includes classroom instruction, on-site training at the plant, and follow-up observation to determine the comprehension and understanding of the new hire. Finally, the company routinely invites local fire department personnel to visit the site. In the event that the local fire department requests assistance in training its employees on anhydrous ammonia, the company cooperates fully in their endeavors.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION/EMERGENCY RESPONSE 



This facility complies with ANSI Standard K-61.1-1999 requirements with amendments for Anhydrous Ammonia storage.  It is our policy to adhere to all applicable Federal, State, and local regulations.  If an emergency were to occur, it is our policy to immediately notify the Oyens Fire Department (via a 911 call) and request that it respond to the emergency.  Incidental to the notification to the fire department, a call to the Plymouth County EMA will be made.



While we have planned for an emergency, it is acknowledged that a real emergency will be unexpected and may be much different and cannot be ensured to duplicate what may have been planned.  In reality, the situation that develops may not happen in the manner in which it has been planned.  In that event, what may have been planned will serve only as a guideline to follow. 



The Emergency Action Plan for this facility describes certain procedures that are intended to minimize the hazards associated with human health and the environment from fires, explosions, the sudden and unexpected release of chemicals (i.e., Anhydrous Ammonia), tornadoes, bomb threats or other accidents or acts of God which might occur on our premises.   The primary emergency coordinator for the facility is the location manager.





DESCRIPTION OF THE ANHYDROUS AMMONIA STORAGE/DISTRIBUTION PLANT AND THE REGULATED SUBSTANCE HANDLED AT FACILITY



This facility is a bulk anhydrous ammonia storage and distribution plant. The anhydrous ammonia, stored at this facility, is distributed to agricultural crop producers in the surrounding area who utilize anhydrous ammonia for crop nutrient purposes.  The system consists of storage vessel(s) with associated piping, valves, liquid pump(s), and other miscellaneous equipment. From time-to-time throughout the year, portable nurse tanks may also be present at this site.  The anhydrous ammonia plant is operated on a seasonal basis (Spring and Fall).

Full-time equivalent employee numbers were computed on that basis.  At a maximum, the plant operates a total of three months (1/4 of the year). The FTEs for this company location is 0.





GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



This facility complies with EPA's accident prevention rule and all applicable State and local codes and regulations.  The anhydrous ammonia system is designed, installed, and maintained in accordance with ANSI Standard K-61.1-1999 with amendments and State law.



In addition, the company has specific operating procedures in place intended to minimize the potential for an accidental (and potentially catastrophic) release of anhydrous ammonia. The company has extended to the local Fire Department the opportunity to visit our anhydrous ammonia plant  and review ammonia health hazard information and training provided by the company.





FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



The facility has not experienced any accidental release involving anhydrous ammonia in the last five years that caused death, injuries, property or environmental damage, evacuations or sheltering in place.





THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM:



In the event of an emergency involving our anhydrous ammonia system, it is the policy of the company to immediately notify the local Fire Department and the Plymouth County EMA to request that they respond to the emergency.  In the unlikely event that the local Fire Department is unable to adequately respond to an emergency at the location, the Fire Department with whom Oyens has a reciprocal agreement will be summoned. We have discussed this policy with the fire department and EMA.  





PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY:



The plan is to minimize those hazards to human health and to the environment that are associated with accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia.  Employees working at the bulk storage plant make routine observations prior to and during transfer operations of the anhydrou

s ammonia from the storage vessel(s) to nurse tanks. In so doing, they are able to detect problems before they arise. This routine inspection identifies any portion of the system which may be under stress or about to fail. Repairs can be made before they become problematic. Employees are annually trained to recognize the hazards associated with storage and handling of anhydrous ammonia. In addition to annual training for employees who have been on the job for a number of years, the company conducts training for new hires. This training includes classroom instruction, on-site training at the plant, and follow-up observation to determine their individual comprehension and understanding of the new hire. Finally, the company routinely invites local fire department personnel to visit the site. In the event that the local fire department requests assistance in training its employees on anhydrous ammonia, the company cooperates fully in their endeavors.
